div.p: Grace and peace from God, etc.
I have received the book back from Brother Wolff; I request, if it is not inconvenient for you, that you also send me the booklet soon, which I lent you on the Concordat trade, etc.

The 4 Schillings have also been received, as well as the 15 Batzen. The remaining debt is still 10 Schillings; you need not worry about it. If I receive something here, I will give it; if not, I will pay it from my own pocket. And no one should be further troubled.
As soon as I have certain news from England, I will share it with you. Nothing has been decided yet regarding Reichenau; the canons of Constance would like it, but my lords and others are resisting.

The Emperor [Charles V] has been in Paris and is now in Flanders. Much pomp is being displayed. I fear that our people will be more hindered by cunning than forced by the sword. In this way, they will be more easily overcome than by force. Our people intend to be honest and brave. May God grant grace.

When I come up to you, I do not wish for any gathering or disturbance or expenses that the brothers have with me; I would rather stay at home. If I come to you, it would be more to escape the hustle and bustle and to enjoy myself with you, one or two at most, etc.
You should be certain about the pieces for the lute. Occasionally send someone here within 8 days to inquire, etc.
I have written in such great discomfort, as I have not had for several months. Farewell.
